ment had been made the day before with Nicholls that I was to have 1l. a dozen—nobody else was present—I had not mentioned to anybody else that I required 15l. on 15 dozen skins—I placed the skins on the barrow—Bennett had never been to Nicholls before; I did not tell him where to go but merely to accompany the prisoner—they left about 20 minutes or a quarter to 11—at half-past one the prisoner came back without the barrow, and asked me if the boy had come back with the barrow—I asked him what boy; I was surprised—he said, "The boy with the barrow"—I said I bad not seen the boy—he said, "The boy would not wait for me on the road when I told him," and that he had gone on to Mr. Nicholls, delivered the goods and got the cheque—I said, "Surely you never trusted that boy with the 15l. cheque?"—he said, "Well, I believe that he has it and no doubt it will be all right"—I said, "That is a funny way to speak"—he said, "The boy is sure to come back because he has got the barrow"—I said, "I don't know so much about that, for if he is so disposed he might run the barrow up any side turning and leave it"—after a little more conversation he asked me what had best be done, and I said he had better go and see if he could find the boy—I believe he did not go—he told me he had been to Mr. Nicholls and arrived about a quarter of an hour after the boy had left—about two o'clock the boy returned and made a statement to me, in consequence of which I went to Mr. Nicholls—next morning when the prisoner came to business I had an interview with him in Detective Harding's presence—I stated the matter to him and told him it was a very bad matter for him as he knew—he denied in toto that he had anything to do with this other man—I told him eventually as he had not confessed to it I had no alternative than to give him into custody.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I could not have given you instructions in the public-house the night before, because I had not made up my mind about them—I told you the day before to make arrangements about the skins, and when you came back I was in a public-house with a friend—you told me in the public-house you had made arrangements with Mr. Nicholls about them, but we were in the private bar, and only spoke in whispers—five or six people were there, some yards away—the bar is 8 by 10 feet, or something like that—I don't know that five or six people were round us—I do not believe they could have heard if they had listened; they must have had sharp ears to hear—Bennett has only been in
my employment a few weeks; I got no character with him—I have not troubled to find out his character since.

GEORGE NICHOLLS . I am an auctioneer, in the shoe and leather trade, at 2 and 3, George Yard, Fenchurch Street—on several occasions I have made advances to Mr. Booth through the prisoner—on Tuesday, 19th October, I saw the prisoner about making a further advance, and it was arranged that on the following day he should bring some morocco skins on which I was to advance 1l. per dozen—on 20th October Bennett called at my place with a young man, bringing 15 dozen morocco skins and this memorandum—I advanced 15l. on the skins, and gave to the young man this cheque for 15l., payable to Mr. Booth's order—it was then without endorsement—this was between 11 and 12—about a quarter of an hour afterwards the prisoner came to my place and said, "Have you received the goods?" or "Have the goods been delivered?"—I said, "I have, and I have advanced a cheque for 15l."—he said nothing more.
Cross-examined. I used to give crossed cheques, and Booth wrote and asked me to give open ones instead—this was an open cheque payable to order.

By the JURY. I don't think I told the prisoner that I had given the cheque to a young man; I merely said the goods had been delivered, and that I had made the advance—the cheque was paid by my bankers over the counter.
Re-examined. I did not 'show the prisoner this memorandum—the conversation about the cheques had been some time back.

HENRY BENNETT . I live at 4, Bronte Place, Trafalgar Road, Old Kent Road—on 20th October, Mr. Booth gave me some instructions to go with a barrow of morocco skins with the prisoner at a quarter to 11—I did not know where I was going with them—I had not taken skins to Mr. Nicholls before—I started with the prisoner and with the barrow; when I got a few yards away from the warehouse, the prisoner asked me if I knew Fenchurch Street—I said, "Yes;" he then followed me till I got to the New Kent Road—I looked round and could see nothing of him—I was there at least ten minutes, when a strange man came up to me, and asked if I worked for Mr. Booth—I said, "Yes"—he said, "I have got to go with you"—I said, "Where is the other man"—he said, "He has got to go somewhere else"—going by the Bull public-house, opposite Weston Street, I saw the prisoner with his face turned towards the public-house doors—he saw me and the strange man go past him, because his face was turned towards me as I went past; he turned round; he was one and a-half or two yards from me—as we were going down the Dover Road, the strange man asked me if I knew Mr. Booth—I said, "Yes"—he said, "He is my father, and young Tom is my brother"—the prisoner's name is Tom Baldwin—when we got to St. George's Church I stopped with the barrow, and the strange man went into the public-house at the corner of Swan Street; then the prisoner came up to me and waved his hand for me to go—I did not know at first what he meant; he then came up and told me to walk on slowly round by St. George's Church—I don't know where the strange man was at this time, but he came back again and followed me—I went round by St. George's Church, and then the strange man took me to Mr. Nicholls', Fenchurch Street; a porter there took the skins into the warehouse—the strange

man went in and wrote on a piece of paper similar to this—I stayed outside with the barrow—when the stranger came out he sent me off with the barrow to Mr. Jones, 202, Commercial Road, to get a half hundred weight of soles for boots—I could not find anyone of the name there; I then came back and told my master what had occurred.

Cross-examined. I knew your name was Tom; I did not know your other name—I thought you were Booth's son when the other man told me you were his younger brother; he did not say he was so—I did not say when Harding was at Mr. Booth's, or at any time, that you went straight on to the Borough with me—you could have gone round from the first place I saw you at to the second by Buckingham Square and the New Kent Road—I did not see you speak to this man; I did not see you have any connection with him at all—I had nothing on the barrow coming back—I came straight back to Mr. Booth's—the man did not come back with me—you did not walk as far as the Swan about 30 yards behind me.

GEORGE WILLIAM REYNOLDS . I live at Weston Road, Amhurst Park, Stamford Hill, and am a clerk at the London and Westminster Bank, Whitechapel Branch—on 20th October I cashed this cheque over the counter between two and three I should think; it was then endorsed "M. W. Booth"—I can't say who presented it.
WILLIAM MERCER BOOTH (Re-examined). This endorsement to this cheque is not mine—the writing on the memorandum is not mine nor the prisoner's.
By the Prisoner. Very possibly I called you "Tom "in the public-house—I was generally in the habit of doing so, and so possibly the people in the public-house would know your name was Tom.
By the JURY. The prisoner had to call on his way with these skins at Mr. Chipperfield's.
By MR. TICKELL. On the Wednesday I determined for the first time to send the skins—I told him he was to call at Mr. Chipperfield's office in Trinity Street, Borough.
By the Prisoner. You had made arrangements with Nicholls to leave the skins on the Wednesday, provided that I approved of the price—I did not give you the name of other pawnbrokers.

HENRY NELSON PHILCOX . I live at 37, Trescot Road, Peckham Road, and am articled clerk to Mr. Chipperfield, of 7, Trinity Street, Southwark, about 10 minutes' walk from the New Kent Road—Mr. Chipperfield is Mr. Booth's solicitor—on 20th October, at 20 minutes past 11, the prisoner came to the office from Mr. Booth, and was there about a quarter of an hour—he paid something on account, and said he was going into the City for some money, and he would come back and pay us—about 20 minutes past 1 that day I saw him on a tram car near St. George's Church, about two minutes' walk from us—he said he had not got the money—I said u That will be rather awkward"—he said "No, it is all right; they have paid the boy; he would not wait for me, and went on without me"—I went with the prisoner to Mr. Booth.

Cross-examined. I am positive about the time, because I saw a lady at 25 minutes to 12; she was with me for half an hour—I left you in the lower office; you afterwards saw Mr. Chipperfield upstairs—you were waiting not five minutes downstairs—when the lady came I left you—I

came into Mr. Chipperfield's office upstairs in a very few minutes—you were to have paid 3l. and only paid 30s.—I did not hear you had lent Mr. Booth 4s. of that—I am not aware he owes you money—you told Mr. Booth the boy had not waited for you.

WILLIAM MERCER BOOTH (Re-examined by the Prisoner). I owe you 5l. or 6l.—you have lent me money at different times, from a few shillings up to 2l.—of the money you were to pay to Mr. Chipperfield 4s. was yours; it left me with not even a shilling—I had no character with you—I thought you were in employment when I had you—I did not know where you worked—you were living at the Turkish baths, I believe—I don't recollect you saying I could have a character from them.
By the COURT. I gave the prisoner into custody.

WILLIAM HARDING (City Detective). About 11 o'clock on Friday morning I saw the prisoner, the prosecutor, and Bennett in the prose
cutor's warehouse—I told the prisoner I was an officer of police, and I had to make some inquiries respecting a cheque for 15l. obtained from Mr. Nicholls, an auctioneer, Nos. 2 and 3, George Yard, Fenchurch Street, on the 20th—I told Bennett to say in the prisoner's presence what he had previously told me and his master. (The witness here repeated the boy's statement, which was substantially the same as that already given in his evidence.)I said "What time did you arrive at Mr. Nicholls' place?"—he said "I think it was something after 1 o'clock"—the prisoner said "I had to call at Mr. Chipperfield's, the solicitor, on my way; I was detained there half an hour"—I said "If that was so you had ample time to get to Mr. Nicholls's warehouse before the boy arrived with the goods"—he turned to his master and said "Well, Mr. Booth, give me in custody; I don't care to be kept in suspense any longer"—he also said "I have never received any wages from Mr. Booth for five or six weeks"—I took him to the Seething Lane Police-station, where I searched him, and found on him 2l. 16s.—he described himself as single, but I found his wife was living at 34, Red Lion Street, Holborn—it is about two miles from Upper Grange Road to George Yard I should think, and more than a mile from Upper Grange Road to Trinity Street, Borough—the weather was very dirty, and the streets greasy—it would take a boy a long time to get from the church to George Yard; he would go over London Bridge.
Cross-examined. It is about half a mile from the New Kent Road to St. George's Church, which is quite close to Mr. Chipperfield's office—I do not know your movements on the Thursday.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence urged that he could not have got in front of the boy for the boy to see him a second time; that if he had had the cheque he would probably have cashed it before 2 or 3 o'clock lest it should be stopped; and he stated that he was detained a long time at Mr. Chipper-field's, and that he thought the boy knew Mr. Nicholls's, and that he had brought away the cheque.

div1.p: MR. TICKELL. said that he wished to withdraw the Count for false pretences, and to go to the Jury upon the conspiracy only.

GUILTY of conspiracy. —
Four Months' Hard Labour.

1111.
HENRY THOMAS PALMER (45)
, Unlawfully obtaining by false pretences from
George Wright 4l. 9s., with intent to defraud.

GEORGEWRIGHT. I keep the Queen Anne public-house, Walworth—on 19th August the prisoner came in with Freeman and a customer—he had a cheque for 4l. 9s. in his hand, and said, "Do you mind obliging me by changing a cheque?—"I said, "I am not in the habit of changing cheques for strangers"—"God love me man," said the prisoner, "this cheque is as good as the Bank of England"—I said "It might be, I have a good deal of trouble sometimes with cheques"—he said, "It came from a diamond merchant, 140, Old Bond Street; I have had many of them from him; if you refer to the Post-office Directory you will see it "—I changed the cheque then—I looked at the Directory afterwards, not at the time; the name was there—he said he was a traveller, that he bad a warrant for four hogsheads of brandy that had landed in the Docks—he went away then—I passed the cheque through my bank; it came back marked "No account, closed"—it is "Pay W. Russell"—it was endorsed ""W. Russell' when he gave it to me, and he endorsed it "H. C Palmer" at my request—two or three days after the cheque was dishonoured I went and saw the prisoner, and told him—he said, "I do not know how it is, I am sure"—I said, "You must make it, good"—he said, "I have no money, I have not a farthing"—I said, "Cannot you make some means of getting some?"—he said "No"—I said, "How did you possess this cheque? who is this Russell?"—he said, 'I don't know Russell at all, all I know is I had it by the first post that morning;" the morning he presented it to me he meant—I said, "You bad better see Mr. Blanc, the drawer, and see if you cannot get the money"—he said he would—I said, "You had better come down and see me and pay me; if you cannot get the money from him, come to me, and I will go down with you to Messrs. Blanc and see what we can do between us'—he never came near me again—I went and saw him again; I got nothing from him—I gave information to the police, and he was arrested—I parted with my money for the cheque, solely on his representation that Mr. Blanc had money at the bank.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You were a stranger, I knew the other two men; one of them did not say "A few days ago you obliged me by changing a cheque, can you do so now for my friend?'—one of them did not introduce you to me—Freeman asked me, after I said I did not change cheques for Grangers, if I found his little cheque all right? and I said that was all right, because I knew the drawer of it—I had a drink with you, you asked me—we had some conversational walked, through Camber well with you and Freeman, and we went into the Tiger—I saw in the Directory what Blanc's business was—I did not ask you for security; I said "If you have anything that is worth anything you had better leave it with me, I will hold it till you pay me"—you said "I have got nothing in my possession I can leave that is worth 4l. 9s"—when I came to see you I said all I wanted was my money, and If you can show me you lose this money, I will lose, half of it with you, if you prosecute Blanc, and I will take it from you, 5s. a week"—you wore to meet me on Monday or Tuesday to take me to see Blanc, you said you could never find him—you never appeared, and I went to the police—the second time you were before the Magistrate I knew Blanc was in custody—I could not pay when he was apprehended.
JAMES DE MOPS . I am chief cashier at the St. James's Branch of the

National Provincial Bank of England—this cheque is signed by Blanc and Co.; they had no account at our bank when this was drawn—their account was closed last December, and an intimation sent them to that effect—Blanc resided at 40, Old Bond Street, and was a diamond merchant—I last saw him in the dock at the Middlesex Sessions—he got five years' penal servitude about a month ago for obtaining money by false pretences by a cheque on our bank—he had kept his cheque book.

ELLEN SAINGER . I live at 12, De Crespigny Terrace, Camberwell, and am a widow—the prisoner came to lodge with me on 28th February, and was there until he was arrested—on 17th August a friend of his named Blanc came to stay with him, and shared his bedroom; he came I thought for one or two days, but stayed nearly ten—I saw him in the dock at Middlesex Sessions, he was sentenced to fire years' penal ser
vitude about a month ago—his address was there given as 40, Bond Street—he went to an hotel after he left me.

Cross-examined. I was away for a few weeks after Blanc left—when I returned you told me he had gone, and said it was because he had behaved in a very dishonourable way to you in some matter of business—on the following Wednesday you told me some one had called from Jay's, in Oxford Street, with reference to a 20l. cheque, and that my address was given on it, and that Blanc had issued it—I was told that cheque was cashed on the 28th, I think—I gave evidence of this against Blanc—your conduct was honourable when you resided with me.

CHARLES VINEY (Detective Sergeant G). I arrested the prisoner on 3rd September, and told him I was a police officer, and I should take him into custody on a warrant for obtaining 4l. 9s. from Wright by false pre
tences on 19th August—he said "I am sorry for that; it is a bad job; it is my own fault, I ought to have gone and seen Mr. Wright as I pro
mised"—I said "You told Mr. Wright you received that cheque by post from 40, Old Bond Street"—he said "Yes, I did"—I said "Blanc has been away from there 12 months"—he made no reply—I said "You told Mr. Wright that you saw Blanc on Saturday last"—he said "I did see him, but I don't know where he lives, or where to find him"—the prisoner asked me if I could let the warrant stand over for a few days—I told him I could not—he said "Well, then, I am sold"—I have made inquiries at 40, Bond Street.
Cross-examined. I was with the prosecutor and another officer—I alone spoke to you.
The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. u When I negotiated that cheque I believed it to be genuine."

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence stated that Blanc owed him money, and had promised to send him some, and that he believed this cheque was genuine.

div1.p:
GUILTY .—
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

1112.
RICHAED WILLIAMS (40)
, Unlawfully carnally knowing
Annie Williams, a girl 13 years old. Other Counts for attempting to have carnal knowledge and for indecent assault.
MR. SALTER Prosecuted; MR. SAFFORD, at the request of the Court, defended the prisoner (who was deaf and dumb).

GUILTY
of an indecent assault. —
Nine Months' Hard Labour ,

1113.
DANIEL DACEY (22)
, Robbery with violence on
George; Samuel Cherubin, and stealing 11s., his money.
MR. SANDERS Prosecuted; MR. HUTTON Defended.

SAMUEL GEORGE CHERUBIN . I live at the Cottage, 600, Commercial Road East, and am a clerk—on 30th September, about 11.30, I was going home, and went into a public-house in the High Street, Borough, and on leaving I counted my money; I had 11s. exactly, which was in my right-hand trousers pocket—I turned into a narrow turning, and while I was unbuttoning my trousers I was attacked by three men from behind; they must have followed me—the prisoner was one of them; he threw his left, arm round me, and took hold of me by the throat, and another took hold, of my left arm, and the third took hold of my right hand with his left hand and placed his right hand into my pocket, and I felt him take my money—I never released the prisoner—I called out; generally to them, particularly the one taking my money, and said "You scoundrel"—the, two men ran away, and a policeman came to my assistance immediately, while I was still on the ground—the three of them threw me to the, ground; it was quite a melee—the prisoner said "Let go"—I was not aware there was a constable, but as soon as I saw it was I let him go, and the constable, assisted by another one, took him to the station, and L then found my money was gone—I was very much hurt, and I felt the effects on my throat for three weeks—I was in bed next day when the constable called; I have recovered now—I had not seen the prisoner before to my knowledge—I had had a glass, but I knew perfectly what I was about—I walked to the station with the constable.

Cross-examined. I put out my hands and seized the first person I could lay hold of, particularly the one that held me—I live from a mile and a half to two miles from this public-house—I had left home in the afternoon, and had been to a wharf where I had been formerly engaged—I had no drink there—I then went to another wharf on this side of the water, and I had a drink of mild and bitter, there with the chief clerk—after that I went over the water; I was in company with other friends—I might have had five or six drinks during the evening, but I should say I was a sober man that evening—I had no whisky; I never touch spirits—if the constable says I was the worse for drink I should say he was mistaken; I was excited—I was at the station no longer than it would require to take the charge; not half an hour—the station was about a quarter of a mile from where this took place—I did not walk beside the constable, I walked behind—he saw me at the station, and I had a conversation with him there.
Re-examined. I was naturally excited and dazed at the injuries I had received.

JOHN WATERMAN (Policeman M 329). I was on duty in the High Street, Borough, about 12 o'clock on the night of 30th September last, and from information I received I went to St. Margaret's Court, a turning out of the High Street, and saw the prosecutor struggling with three men, and I saw him fall; he was about 12 yards up the court—there are some houses at the other end—I went up to him, and the two men saw me coming and started off down the way they came—the prisoner fell down on the top of the prosecutor; I went and pulled him off—the prosecutor had hold of him here, very tight, and when he saw I was a constable he got up and said, "They have robbed me,"

and put his hand in his pocket and said, "They have taken all my money"—the prisoner said they did not do it; he said, 'I am innocent of it; this man struck me in the face, and I am fighting in self-defence"—I Searched the prisoner and found 3d. in coppers in his trouser pocket—I then took him to the station—the prosecutor had been drinking, but he knew well what he was about—the prisoner was quite Sober; in answer to the charge at the station he said he was fighting in self-defence.

Cross-examined. I said at the police-court, "Prosecutor was rather the worse for drink; "he Was the Worse for drink, but knew what he was about—it was dark there, but I could see them—the public-house looks into this road, and a door leads out into it, and the prosecutor was lour or five yards below the door—I was standing across the other side of the road, and when I got up to them I saw the prisoner had hold of the prosecutor on the ground—some passing person gate me the information.

GUILTY .** The prisoner had been 17 times convicted of drunkenness and assault.—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

1114.
WILLIAM ROBERTS (23)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
Martin Willis, and stealing 21 packets of tobacco and 21 pieces of paper, his property.

MARTIN WILLIS . I keep the Queen's Head public-house, Vauxhall Walk—on the morning of 5th October, about 1.45, I went to bed and left everything secure, and was awoke by the dog barking about 3 o'clock; I thought it was barking at nothing and went to sleep again—I got up next morning about 7.30, and found the drawer in the bar had been opened and the tobacco gone; it was safe in the drawer the night before; it was similar to this; I see here 21 packets; the drawer was full—I found that a knife had been put between the two sashes of the landing window that looks into the yard, and the hasp had been newly sawed by the knife—there was nothing in the yard, but he would have the assistance of some steps to get to the window—the yard communi
cates with the street; there is a wall five feet high, but a man could get over it easily—I could not say whether the steps had been used; they always stand in the back yard; they would reach the landing window—the window was safe when I went to bed—I thought I heard a noise on the stairs near the landing window before the dog barked; it ceased barking and I thought it was all right.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I can swear that tobacco is mine, firstly by the name "Fleming; Virginia "on the packet, and secondly I am the the wall by only one in that district they serve—I don't think you could get over yourself; you could easily get back with the assistance of the steps.

WILLIAM WARREN (Policeman L 112). On the morning of 5th October, about 6.30 a.m., 1 was on duty in the New Cut, and saw the prisoner stop a man who appeared to be going to work and hold his hands up as if offering him something, I could not see what it was—I followed him some distance and saw him stop two men; I followed him about 200 yards and overtook him, and asked him what he was offering for sale; he said "I only want to bell this, policeman," putting his hand in his pocket and pulling out a packet of tobacco—I at once put my hand in his right-hand pocket, and found a number of packets—I turned him round and put my

hand in his other pocket, and found a quantity there—it wais a kind of cutaway coat—I said "Where did you get it from?" he said "I bought it last night from a young man Blackfriars Road"—I said "How much did you give for it?" he said "I gave him 1s. for the whole"—I didn't like the answer and took him to the station—I asked him if he knew the man or whether he would know him again—he said "No, I never saw him before"—I searched him at the station and found on him 21 half-ounces of tobacco, 1s. in silver, and some bronze, a pocket-knife, and some other small articles, a reel of cotton, and some matches, you might call them silent matches—this knife has marks on it, and has evidently been used for forcing back something—I charged him with the unlawful possession then, and went to different police-station, but nothing was reported to the police—I then went to Fleming's, 60, Broadway, Lon
don Fields, and got the names and addresses supplied by that firm, and so got from the list the house where this took place—I examined the premises, and found a mark between the window frames of the landing window, such as might have been made by forcing the catch with a knife—I tried to force the catch back with this knife, and was successful; the bottom part of the window lifted up—I saw some steps in the yard; I got on them and could get in by their means—any one could also get over the wall by the aid of them; no one could get over by himself—I could get over—it is a little over 5 feet—when I told the prisoner I should charge him with burglary he said "What, me to be charged with burglary?"—I said "Yes"—he said "My God, it is all up! it is the other man that ought to be charged, not me"—it is about half a mile from the Queen's Head, where I stopped him.

Cross-examined. I searched the yard to try and find the point of this knife, but there had been a lot of rain and it was very dirty—it had recently been broken when I found it on you—the prosecutor was the only one in Lambeth that that firm supplied—I put a name on the tobacco.

The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. "I bought this tobacco and gave 1s. for the lot. I asked him if it was stolen, and he said it was got on the cross; that means it was stolen. I thought I would take my chance. That was about four in the morning."

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence stated that he pleaded guilty to the unlawful possession but not to the burglary.

div1.p:
GUILTY .—He then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction felony at this Court in February, 1885.—
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

p.hi: The Court commended the conduct of the officer, in which the Jury concurred.

div1.p:
1115.
WILLIAM BROWN and
ALBERT GREENAWAY
, Stealing a mare, cart, and harness, the property of
William Small.
MESSRS. POLAND and MATHEWS Prosecuted; MR. A. METCALFE Defended.

WILLIAM SMALL . I am a horse dealer, of 55, Richard Street, Liver
pool Road, Islington—on 9th August I left my horse and cart outside the Elephant and Castle about 4 30 in charge of two men—I came out in halt an hour and they were gone—I gave information at the Islington Police-station—about six weeks afterwards I law the cart and harness in the possession of Bent, a butcher, at Northampton—I gave Bent in custody, but he was discharged.
Cross-examined. I had not seen either of the prisoners before this charge.

MARY ANN DAGY . I keep the Magpie Inn, Northampton—on 14th August the prisoners, a third man, and Brown's wife, came into the yard with a living van, a cart, harness, and a chestnut horse—they staved a week and went on the 21st—Brown lived with his wife in the ran and Greenaway lodged at my house—on the 28th they came again with a third man, and remained half an hour—the third man asked for some note paper; I did not see what they did with it.

Cross-examined. I am quite sure the third man came with them on 14th August—I saw on the Sunday the horse they brought, it had white legs and face; they tell me it was the horse that was stolen—I had seen the third man some four years ago when he came with Greenaway's father and mother into my yard.

ARTHUR BENT . I am a butcher at Harpole, near Northampton—on 18th August I saw the prisoners and a third man—they asked me whether I wanted to sell the cob I had in the market—I said, "I don't mind"—they asked me whether I would make an exchange for the cart—I said I did not mind, and I exchanged my cob for the cart and 7l. 10s.—next day I exchanged my old cart for this cart and set of harness and gave 31s.—all three men were present on both the 18th and 19th August—I had never seen the third man before, I don't know who he was; I have seen him in the market since—on 4th September Small saw these things in my possession—I saw a horse at the Magpie; I don't know what became of it.

Cross-examined. The third man paid me the 7l. 10s.—I knew the two prisoners were with a travelling van—I saw them about the town several days after 19th August—I saw the third man at the Magpie; he was not going about with the van.

SAMUEL PEARSE . I am groom to Henry Ward, Hyde House Farm; Kingsbury, Middlesex—his bay mare was in a field close to his resi
dence at eight o'clock on 30th August—next morning it was gone—I communicated with the police, and on 7th September I went to Northampton, where I saw it in the possession of the police and identified it.

JOSEPH SPENCER CAMPION . I am an auctioneer, of 5, Dorngate, North
ampton—on 4th September, Greenaway brought me this letter—(Requesting the witness to sell a bay mare without reserve—signed, "G. Dennis, Towcester") with a bay mare, which was put in an auction shed—I put her up to sell in consequence of the instructions in this letter; there was no bid for her, and she was taken back to the auction shed, and, here left till she was fetched away, and I saw no more of her.
Cross-examined. I never heard of a Dennis of Towcester—I have been at Northampton all my life—I know Towcester well, and deal much with Towcester people.

ALFRED GREEN (Detective Officer, Northampton). On Saturday, 4th Sep
tember, about 6.30, I saw the two prisoners at Wootton, nearly two miles from Northampton—I told them they would be charged on suspicion of stealing a horse, cart, and harness, from the Old Kent Road, on or about 9th August—Bent had accompanied us, and he said, "These are two of the men; that is my cart and harness, they had it in their possession"—Greenaway said he bought that in the market of a man, he did not know who—Brown said he did not know who the man was—they had a van and cart, too, and a bay mare which was drawing the van—

Brown said he bought the mare that day in the market to draw the van, because the pony was not strong enough—Greenaway said, "We were afraid we should get into trouble for overloading the pony, so sold the pony, and bought the horse"—I took them in custody—on September 7th Pearse came down to Northampton and identified the mare that had been in the van a Mr. Ward's property, and took it back to London—Small's cart and harness I found at the Magpie in the landlord's possession, and Bent's cart and harness were in the prisoner's possession—Towcester is eight miles from our place; I don't know much about it.
Cross-examined. I have not made inquiries at Towcester as to whether there was a person names Denis there—the case was handed over to the Metropolitan Police.

WILLIAM CROSTON (Detective Sergeant M). On 7th September I went to Northampton, and received the prisoners into custody; I charged them with stealing a horse and cart, the property of Small, from outside the Elephant and the Castle—Greenaway said, "We did not steal the horse and car; nobody saw us take it, and I don't know what you can do with us"—I said, "It was traced to your possession, at all events at the Magpie Inn; you are two of the three men who sold it to a butcher there"—Green-away was going to speak; Brown stopped him and said, "You shut up, let me speak; I own we were present at the time; we had our say in the matter, and he," pointing to Greenaway, "had 1s. of the money, and we had been; we had nothing to do with the stealing, the other man stole it, not us"—I said, "Can you tell us who the third man is?"—he said "No"—I said there was a second charge against them with respect to the mare from a field at Hendon on the night of 30th August—Brown said, "We did not steal the mare, we borrowed it"—I asked him who from he said, "I don't know who from, I don't know the man"—I said, "Does the man know you then?"—he said "No"—I said, "When or where were you to have returned it to him?'—he said, "I don't know—Inspector Blatch was there and said, "You told me you bought it"—Brown said, "That is nothing;" he laughed and made light of it; "We borrowed it of the man that stole it, and that is the bloke you have not got."
Cross-examined. I took a note at the time of their answers to me—I have no doubt there is a third man; every inquiry has been made, but we cannot find him.
Re-examined. We have made inquiries at Towcester for a man named Dennis, but no such person is knows there.

1116.
WILLIAM BROWN and
ALBERT GREENAWAY were again indicted for
stealing a mare, the property of
Henry Ward.
MR. CHARLES MATHEWS, for the prosecution, offered no evidence.

1117.
EPHRAIM OTTEN (20)
, Feloniously wounding
Samuel Allen, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.
SAMUEL ALLEN . I am a lobourer, living at Kennington—on Saturday, 2nd October, I went to play a game of cricket on Clapham Common—while running after the ball I knocked against the prisoner; I said

"I beg your pardon"—we started to come home by tram about a quarter to 11—the prisoner sat on the tram behind me with his back to me—I felt something come on my head; I looked round and saw him with an open knife in his hand and found blood coming from my head—I tried to get the knife from him; it came across this linger, which will be of no more use to me—a witness kept hold of me and said, "Keep quiet"—the prisoner tried to get at my throat through my handkerchief, and then he leaned over the witness's arm and stabbed me in the breast—I called out, "I am stabbed"—a policeman came up and I was taken to a doctor—we had had a little drop, but knew what we were doing—there had been no quarrel between us.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I did not hit you because you would not stop singing.

CHARLES RIVENHALL (Policeman W 140). At 20 minutes to 12 on the night of 2nd October I was in the Clapham Road, and saw a tram coming along from Clapham Common with a number of men singing on the top—when the tram was about to stop I heard some one on the top halloa out "I am stabbed!"—I ran up to the top of the tram, and saw the prisoner being held down and the prosecutor bleeding from his head, hand, and breast—I apprehended the prisoner, and handed him over to another constable—he had been drinking, but knew what he was doing—he said "I don't care for my head; I would as soon have it off as on"—Harris gave me this knife covered with blood.

WIILLIAM HARRIS (Policeman W R 19). I was with Rivenhall on 2nd October—I picked up this knife from the ground all over fresh blood on the left side of a tramcar, which was the side on which the prisoner was sitting.

CHALES DOWNING . I am a surgeon of Clapham—at 20 minutes to 12 on 2nd October the prosecutor was brought to me—he was bleeding very profusely from the left side of his head, and had an incised and lacerated wound on the middle finger of his left hand, which had cut away the tendons of the finger, and an artery was bleeding very freely; I secured this—evidently he had lost a considerable quantity of blood—on his index finger was a clean incised wound—on the right side of his chest, a little way from the breast bone, between his fourth and fifth ribs, there was a wound about three-quarters of an inch deep, obliquely, not penetrating the chest cavity—he had another incised cut behind his right ear, and a scratch on the ear itself—the wound on the finger, if not attended to, might have bled to a dangerous extent—the wounds might have been caused by this knife—the wounds on the head and chest fitted exactly with the point of it—he will probably lose the use of his finger; it will be perfectly stiff.

BENJAMINTRIM. I live at Gray's Place, Lambeth—on the night of 2nd October I was on a tramcar coming from Clapham, and was sitting near the prosecutor and the prisoner on the same side—just before we came to Dorset Street they were singing, and the prosecutor jumped up and laid he was stabbed in the head—I got up and asked him to sit down till the car stopped, and then we would see what it was—I looked round; the prisoner was facing him—I put my hands on the prosecutor's shoulder, and said "Sit down"—he said "Am 1 to sit down and be stabbed in this manner?"—at the same time the prisoner leant over my arm and stabbed him in the breast—I did not see anything in his hand
then, but when I turned round his brother and a witness had hold of him, and I saw a knife in his right hand—the prisoner had been drinking—the prosecutor was sober.

JOHN EMERY . I live at 14, Vauxhall Street—on 2nd October I was on this tramcar, sitting next to the prisoner—I heard the prosecutor say he was stabbed—I turned round and assisted his brother in preventing the prisoner from doing anything more—the prisoner was stabbing him—I held the prisoner back—I had not noticed any quarrel between them.
The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate. "He started it himself. We were singing, and because I would not leave off he started hitting me, and that is how the bother started."

p.hi: The prisoner stated in his defence that if he had used the knife he must have done so under the influence of fit, to which he was subject.

div1.p:
GUILTY *—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

1118.
EDWARD DAVIS and
SAMUEL CHAPMAN
, Feloniously diverting certain points on
the London, Chatham and Dover Railway, with intent to destroy certain engines and carriages.

THOMAS LEONARD . I am an engine driver in the employ of the Lon
don, Chatham and Dover Rail way—on Sunday, 19th September, I was in the coal shed at the locomotive depot, between Queen's Road and Stewart's Lane, with Hawkshaw, a Dover driver, and Cook, who was on my engine—we were about 50 or 60 yards from my turntable—I saw the prisoners coming together from the direction of Queen's Road, Bat
tersea; they came across to the turntable which we turn the engines on, they took the fastenings out at both ends of the table—they are the only things that hold it from moving when we go on and off with our engines, and with the fastenings off most probably the engine would run off the line and go into the hole, which is from 5 ft. 6 in to 6 ft. deep—the prisoners went on in the direction of Stewart's Lane—I and the Dover driver followed, telling two firemen we were going, and they also followed—I got up to the prisoners first—I asked Chapman if they knew the mischief they had been up to; he drew a spanner from under his coat, (he had taken it from the Company's premises), and swung it round and hit me on the ribs as hard as he could, I think—Davis struck me on the head with this stone bottle in a basket—I was incapacitated for some time.

CHARLES COOK . I am a fireman in the employ of the London, Chatham and Dover Railway Company—I was with Leonard at the locomotive depot, Stewart's Lane, and saw the two prisoners together—Chapman, who is nicknamed Sambo, came and pulled out the first catch, and Davis walked across the table and pulled the other catch out—I was on the engine at the time—they passed about 15 yards from my engine, and as they did so Sambo picked up this spanner from a heap of broken chains and fish plates and walked away with it—Leonard came to me, and I followed with him—Leonard asked Chapman what he thought he was doing there—he turned and abused him, and hit him with the spanner across the ribs—Leonard hit him down, but he flourished the spanner about and ran away—Davis hit Leonard with a stone bottle and ran away—I and another witness followed him down Stewart's Lane until
we came to a gang of men—they said "Don't come any farther, old fellow, or you will get murdered."

JOHN GRAVES . I am a fireman in the employ of the London, Chatham and Dover Railway Company—on Sunday, 19th September, I was in this locomotive depot—I saw the two prisoners come from Queen's Road and cross the turntable, where they pulled the catches out—they then went over the bridge into the road, and we went after them to stop them—Leonard was going to capture Chapman, but he struck him with the spanner, and afterwards Davis struck him with a bottle—they got away.

MARY JANE ALLEN . I am the wife of Nicholas Allen—we live at the London Steam Saw Mills, Stewart's Lane—on Sunday afternoon, 9th September, I was sitting outside my door with a baby in my arms—I saw the two prisoners come round the corner; Chapman had a spanner in his hand—he put it on a post, and said if he gave one of them a knock on the head with that it would soon settle them—soon after I saw Leonard come over the fence—he said "It is well you are gone"—they returned with foul language, and he went to Davis and asked who did it—he turned to arrest Chapman, and he hit him with the spanner in the ribs, but he meant it for his head, and when his mate went to arrest him he swung the spanner that no one should arrest him—I called for my husband, but he did not hear me—Leonard went to him, and he up with the bottle and hit him on the head, and when he found he had knocked him down and stunned him, he up with the bottle and hit him on the head, and then ran away.

FREDERICK REED . I live at 22, Stockdale Road, Battersea and am an errand boy—on this Sunday I was in the Stewart's Lane depot—I saw Sambo hit Leonard with the spanner across the ribs, and then Leonard struck him; then they went to arrest Davis, and Davis up with the bottle and knocked him down.

CHARLES EVERTT (Police Sergeant W 42). I arrested Davis—I read the warrant to him; he said that he was there at the time, but he did not do anything, it was Sambo and Carter—I said "Where is the spanner?"—he said "Sambo had it, and I am not going to suffer for others."
CONELIUS MONAHAN (Policeman W 275). I arrested Chapman—I read the warrant to him; he said "I know nothing at all about it."

p.hi: Davis in his defence stated that he saw Amos shift the catches, and that he only hit Leonard with the bottle after Leonard had hit him. Chapman stated that Amos had moved the catches, and that he hit Leonard with a piece of wood, not with a spanner.

div1.p: GUILTY .

CHAPMAN then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony in March, 1883.
They were further indicted for assaulting
Thomas Leonard, to which they

PLEADED GUILTY . CHAPMAN—
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.
DAVIS—
Eight Months' Hard Labour.

1119.
ALEXANDER SMITH (29),
Stealing a gelding, the goods of
William Conolly.

WILLIAM CONOLLY . I live at 100, Putney Bridge Road—on 29th Sep
tember, at 6.15 a.m., I missed my pony, which I had last seen at 6.30 the evening before locked up in the stable, the key of which was in my pocket—next morning the lock of the door was broken open.

ALFRED MAYOR . I am in Mr. Conolly's service—on 28th September I was cleaning the stable out, and noticed two men looking over the gate; the prisoner was one of them—the pony was in the yard at the time—I heard the prisoner say, "It is a nice quiet pony"—next morning I iden
tified the prisoner at Battersea Police-station; he had a blue jacket and trousers—I saw the pony in the greenyard.

PERCY WOOD (Policeman V 394). On 29th September, at 12.15, I was in the York Road and saw the prisoner leading a pony—I stopped and asked him where he was going—he said he was going to Vauxhall to take the pony to his master, Mr. White—having no halter or bridle on it aroused my suspicions, and I took him to the station—I searched and found in his pocket this chisel and pocket book—I examined, the stable door and found on it marks corresponding to this chisel—the prosecutor identified his pony at the police-court.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence stated that he was taking the pony to Vauxhall for a man who employed him.

div1.p:
GUILTY .—
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

1120.
JAMES HARRIS (21)
, Unlawfully committing an act of gross indecency with
Henry Littleton.

GUILTY .—
Six Months' Hard labour.

1121.
WILLIAM BROWN (30)
PLEADED GUILTY
to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Christopher Robinson, and stealing a dock.—
Twelve Months' Hard Labour. And

1122.
JAMES ROGERSON (34)
to stealing and receiving two railway warrants, the property of
the Queen, he being employed in the public service;
also to three indictments for forging warrants for the payment of money.—
[Pleaded guilty. See original trial image.]
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, NOVEMBER 22ND, 1886.
